prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the AITA story is in the wrong. The scenario is about a 15-year-old who received a $400 gift card, got pressured by family to buy gifts for everyone, and then decided not to buy anything for them, which led to conflict with their mom.

First, I need to break down the key points. The author received a gift card and shared it on Instagram. The sister found out, then the mom got involved, adding more people to the list. The author felt pressured and decided to keep the money for themselves after getting annoyed by the demands. The mom was upset when the author didn't buy gifts.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. Let's consider both sides. On one hand, the author is a minor, 15 years old, and the gift card was received through a drawing. The family members, especially the mother, might feel entitled to gifts since the author got money. However, the author was pressured and felt the requests were excessive, especially for cousins they don't see often. The author also gave a gift to a friend, which might indicate they're willing to give, but not to family under pressure.

The author's actions could be seen as reasonable if they felt coerced. The mom might have overstepped by adding more people without considering the author's financial comfort. The author's decision to use the money for personal needs and a friend could be justified if they felt the family was being greedy.

On the other hand, some might argue that the author should have considered family expectations, especially during Christmas. The mother might have expected gifts as a gesture of family tradition. However, the author's age and financial responsibility as a teenager might be a factor. At 15, they might not have a lot of money, and being pressured to spend a large gift card on others could be seen as unfair.

The key issue here is the pressure from family members. The author made a choice based on feeling that the family was being greedy. They also mentioned they are very conservative with money, which adds to their perspective. The argument between the author and mom seems to stem from the mom's insistence and the author's reaction to that pressure.

Considering these points, the author's decision to not buy gifts for family after being pressured might be justified. They had the right to decide how to use their money, especially since the gift card was a personal win. The family's reaction might be more about their expectations than the author's actions. So, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong.
